fields.headline: Letter: Amryl Johnson
fields.bodyText: Fred Sedgwick writes: Amryl Johnson (Obituary, March 29) had a sensitivity to what it is to be a child; and the tension she encountered between her Trinidad and Coventry homes is in poems I used in Collins Primary Poetry (1994). The greater affection is always for Trinidad: Back home the sea at we back door I could step out of the house and run down to bathe... But I not back home I here in England where the sun not so hot... She wrote beautifully about emerging into womanhood: Afraid I slowly reached to touch my own eyes nose my mouth to make sure they were straight not crooked like the silver web spider's web holding fast to my looking glass
